<div class="hero-section">
  <h1 class="hero-title">Emily Miller</h1>
  <p class="hero-subtitle">Environmental Data Scientist • Artist • Researcher</p>
</div>

<div class="section-card">
  <h2>Research</h2>
  <p>Currently pursuing a PhD in Environmental Data Science at UCSB, where I develop machine learning models to analyze satellite imagery and track environmental changes across Sub-Saharan Africa. My research focuses on applying computer vision and deep learning techniques to biodiversity conservation, wildlife corridor mapping, and indigenous land rights monitoring.</p>
  
  <p>Beyond the laboratory, I am actively involved in community environmental initiatives and beach cleanup organizations in Isla Vista, exploring how data-driven insights can translate into meaningful environmental action.</p>
  
  <p><em>Equal parts quantitative rigor and unreasonable hope.</em></p>
</div>

<div class="section-card">
  <h2>Creative Practice</h2>
  <p>Beyond the laboratory, I maintain an active creative practice that encompasses visual art, photography, and poetry. I believe that creativity and scientific inquiry are complementary forces — both require careful observation, pattern recognition, and the courage to explore the unknown.</p>
  
  <p>My artistic work often draws inspiration from the data patterns I encounter in my research, creating visual bridges between quantitative analysis and aesthetic expression.</p>
</div>

  <h2>Background</h2>
  <p>A former mathematics major who discovered that data science offers the perfect intersection of analytical rigor and practical application. I am passionate about using technology to address environmental challenges while maintaining a commitment to community engagement and creative expression.</p>
  
  <p>My work spans the intersection of remote sensing, machine learning, and environmental justice, with a particular focus on making complex data accessible and actionable for communities around the world.</p>
